Introduction to strain measurement

 

Electrical Resistance strain gages

 

Lord Kelvin, in 1856, loaded copper and iron wires in tension and noted that their resistance increased with the strain applied to the wire. Mathematically, we note that the resistance R of a uniform conductor with length L, cross sectional area A and specific resistance s is given by:
R = s L /A
Differentiating , we get:
dR/R = ds /s + dL/L -dA/A
The term dA represents the change in cross-sectional area of the conductor due to transverse strain which is equal to -vdL/L where v is the Poissons ratio. If the diameter of the conductor before the application of load is d0 then the above equation after simplification becomes:
dR/R = ds/s + dL/L (1+2v)
Here the term dL/L is equal to the applied strain e. We can now define the term " Strain sensitivity " as follows:
Strain sensitivity SA = (dR/R)/ (dL/L)
The strain sensitivity of most metallic alloys is between 2 and 4. A list of some metallic alloys together with their sensitivities is given below: 


          

            

              
Material

              
Composition

              
Strain    Sensitivity

              
Remarks 

            

            

              
Constantan

              
45% Ni 55% Cu

              
2.1

              
General Purpose

            

            

              
Nichrome V

              
80% Ni 20% Cr

              
2.1

              
High Temperature Applications

            

            

              
Platinum Tungsten

              
92% Pt 8% W

              
2.1

              
High Temperature Applications

            

          

          
 

          
Gage Construction

                

            It is theoretically possible to use a single length of  wire 
              as the sensing element of the strain gage. Circuit considerations 
              such  as heat dissipation from the gage and overloading of  power 
              supply place certain restrictions on the resistance and hence the 
              size of the strain gage. The shortest gage length available in  a 
              metal  foil  gage  is 0.008 in. while  the  longest  gage  length 
              available is 4.00 in. Standard gage resistances are 120 ohms  and 
              350 ohms. 

            

              The earliest electrical resistance strain gages were of  the 
              unbonded  type  where the conductors were straight  wires  strung 
              between a fixed frame and a movable frame. The new type of strain 
              gages  are of bonded type. The required length of wire is  formed 
              into  a  grid pattern. In the metal foil strain gages,  the  grid 
              configuration  is  formed  from  metal  foil  by  a  photoetching 
              process. The etched metal film grids are very fragile and easy to 
              distort. Hence the metal foil is usually bonded to a thin plastic 
              sheet,  which serves as a backing. The carrier also serves as  an 
              electrical  insulation between the gage and the  component  after 
              the gage is mounted. Some of the other types of carrier  material 
              are paper and more recently, polyimide. 

            

            Gage Sensitivities and Gage factor 

            

            In a bi-axial strain field, 

              dR/R = Sa ea+ St et+Sat eat 

          
 where ea,et and eat are normal,transverse  and  shear strains 
            respectively. 

            

            Normally Sat = 0 

            Thus dR/R = Sa ( ea + et * Kt)   where Kt =Transverse Sensitivity
            
            Strain gage manufacturers normally provide a calibration constant 
            called the  "Gage Factor"  and denoted by Sg. The gage factor for 
            each  lot  of gages is determined by mounting sample gages  on  a 
            calibration  beam  which  is  deflected  (under  uniaxial  stress 
            condition) a specific distance to produce a known strain  e1. The 
            transverse  strain  e2  is  then equal to -v0 *e1 where v0 is the 
            Poissons ratio of the calibration beam. The change in  resistance 
            of the strain gage is then 

            

            dR/R = Sa e1 (1 - v0 * Kt) 

            or Gage Factor Sg = Sa ( 1- v0 * Kt) 

            It  is important to know that error will occur in  a  strain 
            gage measurement when the equation dR/R = Sg * Strain is employed 
            in  a bi-axial strain field. It can be proved that the  magnitude 
            of this error is of the order 5 micro-in/in. or less for Kt=.0001
            for strains in the elastic region. 
          


              Wheatstone Bridge Circuit
          


              The Wheatstone bridge consists of four resistances join-
                -ed at points A,B,C and D. Voltage V is applied across the poin- 
                -ts A and C and voltage drop E is measured across points B and D 
          


              
          


              The equation relating the output voltage E  to the changes in the
                resistances is : 

            

                E = -  Vr  [ dR1/R1 - dR2/R2 + dR3/R3 - dR4/R4] / (1+r)2 

  

              where dR1,dR2,dR3 and dR4 are small changes in resistances R1, R2
              R3 and R4 respectively. 

              

          
Common bridge arrangements

          
 

          

            


                

                 

            

            
 

            
Commerical Strain Indicators 

            
 

            
One  of  the  commonly used bridge  arrangement  for  static 
              strain  measurement  uses a reference bridge in addition  to  the 
              externally  supplied bridge. In this arrangement,  the  reference 
              bridge  contains  fixed  or variable resistors.  When  gages  are 
              placed  in  the external bridge, the variable resistance  in  the 
              reference  bridge is adjusted to obtain initial balance.  Strains 
              producing  resistance  changes in the external  bridge  cause  an 
              unbalance  between  the  two  bridges  and  an  associated  meter 
              deflection.  This  meter  deflection is  nulled  out  by  further 
              adjusting  the  variable resistor in the  reference  bridge.  The 
              movement of the variable resistor is directly calibrated to  read 
              strain values.
